thread.title: Eight Israelis were wounded, three of them seriously, in fou
thread.title_full: Eight Israelis were wounded, three of them seriously, in fou

author: Nir Hasson
title: Eight Israelis were wounded, three of them seriously, in fou
text:
Eight Israelis were wounded, three of them seriously, in four different stabbing attacks around the country Thursday. Of the four terrorists, one was shot to death, two were arrested and the fourth escaped.
The first terror attack happened in the early afternoon, when a Palestinian stabbed a 25-year-old Israeli at the light rail station on Jerusalem’s Bar-Lev Street. The victim suffered serious stab wounds in his upper body and was evacuated to the capital’s Shaare Zedek Medical Center.
Israeli policeman reacts at the site where a 19-year-old Palestinian man stabbed a 25-year-old Jewish man in Jerusalem on October 8, 2015 AFP The terrorist tried to flee, but policemen nearby ran after him and arrested him. Another man was lightly wounded as police sought to overpower the assailant.
The attacker was named as Subhi Ibrahim Mohammed Abu Khalifa, 19, of East Jeruslem’s Shoafat refugee camp. Later in the day, fierce clashes erupted in the camp between Palestinian residents and the policemen who sought to search Abu Khalifa’s house.
During those clashes , Israeli police shot and killed a 20-year-old Palestinian man and wounded at least six other people. Violent confrontations between Palestinians and Israeli soldiers broke out across the West Bank.
Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu looks on during a press conference on October 8, 2015, at his office in Jerusalem. AFP In a news conference Thursday night, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu called on opposition leader Isaac Herzog, chairman of Zionist Union, to join a unity government, a overture Herzog immediately rejected, calling on Netanyahu to resign. The prime minister also refrained from verbally attacking Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas and stressed he sought his cooperation in curbing the ongoing violence in Israel and the West Bank.
Later in the afternoon, a Palestinian stabbed five people with a screwdriver at an intersection near the Defense Ministry in Tel Aviv. The five victims – a 20-year-old female soldier, two men aged 30 and 40, and two women aged 40 and 60 – were all lightly wounded. They were taken to the city’s Ichilov Hospital for treatment.
The terrorist tried to flee, but an Israel Defense Forces officer who was present at the scene chased after him and shot him dead.
Police at the scene of the stabbing near Azrieli Mall in Tel Aviv, October 8, 2015. Moti Milrod The Shin Bet security service identified the terrorist as Thaer Abu Ghazaleh, 19, from the Kafr Aqeb neighborhood of East Jerusalem. He was apparently employed at a construction site not far from the scene of the attack, which took place at the corner of Begin Road and Mozes Street.
Shortly after that incident, a Palestinian stabbed a 25-year-old man at the western entrance of the West Bank settlement of Kiryat Arba. The victim, who was seriously wounded, was evacuated to Shaare Zedek. The terrorist managed to flee, and the security services are now hunting for him.
Police fire tear gas canisters in Hebron Reuters Finally, Thursday evening, a Palestinian stabbed a 21-year-old soldier on Arlosoroff Street in Afula. The victim, who was stabbed repeatedly, was evacuated to the city’s Haemek Hospital in moderate to serious condition.
The terrorist was a 20-year-old resident of the West Bank. He was arrested and taken in for questioning.
After the terrorist had been overpowered, several angry bystanders tried to attack him. Three policemen who were there protected him with their bodies were injured by the mob. The bystanders also attacked a Channel 2 television news crew that had come to cover the attack.
Thursday’s attacks bring the total number of stabbings over the past two days to seven. On Wednesday, there were three such attacks .
Palestinian killed in clahses
The Palestinian killed by police was Usam Hasam Faraj, 20, of the Shoafat refugee camp. According to medical staff in the camp, he was hit in the chest by a bullet fired by a Ruger rifle.
A Palestinian medical source from Shoafat reported that at least six people were wounded either seriously or moderately by gunfire from a Ruger rifle at the refugee camp. At least one was wounded in the eye, one in the chest and one in the head. They were evacuated to a Ramallah hospital.
Clashes continued in the afternoon Thursday between young Palestinians and Israel Defense Force soldiers in Bethlehem, at the Beit El checkpoint in the Ramallah area, at Beit Omar and El Arub south of Bethlehem, at the Halhul bridge in Hebron and in the Tul Karm industrial zone, the Voice of Palestine radio reported.
During his news conference, Netanyahu called for a “broad” government and unity among Israelis. “The decision on whether to join the government is in the hands of the opposition,” he said. Nevertheless, he added that the security situation would have been much worse than it is now had Zionist Union formed the government after the March 17 election, saying, “Everyone knows what would have happened if we hadn’t been here and somebody else was.”
Herzog rejected the invitation to join the coalition, calling on Netanyahu to resign. “Israel has had another difficult day. The citizens of Israel, the army and the security forces are facing a wave of terrorism with bravery and determination, but they need a prime minister, not the head of a public relations machine,” he said.
Nir Hasson
Haaretz Correspondent
